JEREMY UTLEY: So just
by way of introduction, I think I know many of
you, I'm Jeremy Utley. I'm accompanied-- PERRY KLEBAHN: Hi, Jeremy.

JEREMY UTLEY: --by
Perry Klebahn. And then our amazing team,
Kathryn Segovia and Jao are in the background, making
everything happen as well.

So welcome to the Masters of
Creativity series, session one. Let's see, I'll kick it off.

I'm going to try to share my
screen, Perry, just let me know if that actually works, OK? PERRY KLEBAHN:
Well the good news is, if you want to
follow along and chat,

I've dropped in the deck,
you can download it. So if that's easier for you
and you want to do it that way,

or you want to grab our
materials, you know, please do. JEREMY UTLEY: You know,
Perry's the kind of guy,

if you ever sit by
Perry on an airplane, he's fast-forwarding
through most movies. PERRY KLEBAHN: To the end.

[LAUGHTER] To the end. JEREMY UTLEY: If you want to
fast-forward through this talk, you can actually download
the slides at this link

and you can go at
your own speed. Unfortunately, you can't
get us to talk faster, but you can at least take a
sneak peak and look ahead.

But we're excited to
be with you all today. We want to start-- for those
of you who we don't know, we want to tell you a little bit
about where we're coming from

and what led us actually to
want to host this talk series. PERRY KLEBAHN: Awesome. So a little bit
of our background.

We have so many
interesting past students of many different classes
here, so you've probably

come through one of
these windows here. So if you think
about the work we

do with students at Stanford,
along with Kathryn who runs this program, Leading
Disruptive Innovation-- there's

a few of you past
students there-- we call it d.leadership
is the class.

And it's a class
that we actually put students into organizations
to lead change efforts using

design tools. And it can be a lot of
fun and pretty wild.

And then the other
one is LaunchPad, which is an accelerator
using design

methods to launch businesses,
for profits, nonprofits. It's been around 11 years.

So many companies. But visit the website
and take a look at that if you're interested. And there's lots of sort
of interesting tools

and techniques related
to the early work there. I see a few of the founders,
even from this year,

in the group today, so welcome. And then with the executives
and professionals, we do bootcamps, or
other types of programs

that are intense
programs, that happen at Stanford or online, that
are synchronous and involve--

Kathryn is a big part of that. Jao's a big part that. We put on these huge efforts. And we just did one
a few weeks ago.

And then Stanford Online, which
I think there's many of you here that came through the SI&E
program, which is a program we

invite you to look at. It goes through all the tools
and techniques of design, as well as leading design that's
available at Stanford Online.

So welcome. I thank everybody who came
through one of those windows, most likely.

JEREMY UTLEY: I'm going to
try to hit the eraser here, I don't know how that works--
boom, look at that, nailed it.

Buck, welcome from SI&E,
good to have you with us. PERRY KLEBAHN: [INAUDIBLE] JEREMY UTLEY: So
Perry just shared

a little bit of
the various windows that folks might
be coming through. One of the things that we
have been curious about

is what are the tools
that folks lean on. And increasingly, we're finding
that some of the tools and some

of the entryway points
that we have established through executive education and
other programs at the d.school

are getting a little worn. You might notice the
hexagons are starting to look a little tired and we
think less and less in terms

of this kind of hexagon-driven,
formulaic recipe-driven

approach. If you think back to where Perry
and I-- what Perry and I looked like when we started
with the hexagons,

we were barely out of high
school practically, OK. A lot has changed. I've been out of the country.

I've been through multiple pairs
of glasses and major surgery for crying out loud. PERRY KLEBAHN: But also
that photo of you, Jeremy,

I still think--
just maybe audience vote, how much does he look like
George Costanza, with the vest on.

I think personally, a lot. JEREMY UTLEY: It's the Costanza
photo, please drop it in chat.

If there's any other crazy
characters, drop it in chat. But one of the things
that we have observed as we've been doing this
work inside organizations

and with graduate
students is, there's this focus on the sprint. And by the way, we value
the sprint quite a bit,

the idea of a short burst
of high-intensity work. If you're coming from LaunchPad,
you know we value the sprint,

we're often getting
folks to sprint. But we find that basically
reducing the design

thinking-driven
approach to a sprint is like telling somebody who
needs to come up with ideas,

especially good ideas, the
ideas they can implement and commercialize, it's
like say, just grab a couple of ideas from the
grocery store on your way home.

With the jug of milk and with,
you know, the bunch of kale, pick up a couple of ideas too.

And increasingly, as we're
immersed in organizations, as we're connected with
you all as our alums, we're finding it's not
really how innovation works

and it's not really
how creativity works. Creativity, if we have to think
about a different metaphor

and practices, and mindsets. And there's a lot more
attention on a daily basis,

less in terms of sprinting
and more in terms of what we would think of as practice. And if you like the
sprint metaphor,

then you might think about the
daily activities as stretching, and as training,
and as warming up.

Sprinting is great. It's very important. We love it. But unless your life is
marked by a set of warm-ups,

and stretches, and
practices, you're probably going to pull a hammy
if you start sprinting, right. And you've probably seen that
in the context of your work.

It's just like drop
and give me a 400. You go, uh, right now, like I
haven't even stretched, right. A lot of times creative
action and innovation

efforts are kind of reduced down
to that start sprinting now, immediately, go. And it doesn't have
respect for the system

that a creative mind lives in,
and what their practice is, and attitudes to cultivate that
creative mindset actually are.

So we kind of want to take a
step back from design practice and even from innovation
itself, and talk

about the system and the
environmental factors that enable creativity,
individual and team

creativity, to flourish. PERRY KLEBAHN: So establishing
our sort of premise

for this series is that
creativity is a craft and you hone it
through practice. Then, what does that
make us, Jeremy?

Well, it makes us kind of
like personal trainers. So we'll date
ourselves a little bit

here, Saturday Night Live,
Hans and Franz, to pump you up. It's hysterical.

If you don't know what
we're talking about, Google Hans and Franz, Saturday
Night Live, Dana Carvey,

it is hysterical. Anyway so-- but the
idea is thinking about personal trainers
work directly with you

and sort of almost find a way
for these tools and techniques to fit into your life. And that's what we
think of these sessions.

And it's not, what Jeremy
said, like this perfect project and I'm going to
use all these tools.

But actually, really,
we hope you see today just three techniques that
work against all kinds

of different things in your
life, whether group activities, or individual activities,
personal life, professional life, that
you can apply directly.

So the series
itself, we're going to be doing four
different sessions.

You are in the
input-obsession session. We will cover collaboration,
experimentation,

and updating your creative
operating system to trademark,

you know, us today,
because we just came up with that before this talk.

But the whole idea is really
sort of circling around this idea of practice
and these would

be different lenses,
different sort of categories of techniques to build your
practice around creativity.

JEREMY UTLEY: So part
of the fundamental myth

is that creativity
is about output and we mention this in kind
of our correspondence leading

into this session. Most folks, when they
think about creativity, they think about a
creative outcome.

And that's not the way to
think about creativity.

Arthur Koestler did some
research in the mid-1960s and this is one of my
favorite definitions,

"Creativity is the collision of
two apparently unrelated frames of reference."

And you can think about, one
frame is your brain today, a different frame is your
brain tomorrow, et cetera, but what you're colliding
your brain with,

the outcomes of those collisions
are creative outcomes. But instead of thinking
about creativity

being the outputs of your
effort, what we would recommend is saying creativity is actually
a function of the inputs you're

feeding the system. And what we've observed among
highly successful and creative

individuals is that they
are relentless, and focused,

and rigorous about
cultivating inputs of mind in order to lead to
creative outputs.

So a lot of us who
are not experienced creatives, or we don't
come from creative fields, when we hear about creativity,
we think about drawing,

or we think about
the arts, or we think about some kind of
outcome that looks beautiful. And what we know, actually
from immersing in organizations

and immersing with
creative professionals, is that creatives are way more
concerned with their inputs.

As an example, my wife's
a fashion designer and she goes on these
inspiration trips

to New York and Paris. I think it's because
she likes macarons, but the truth is she's
looking at color,

she's looking at silhouette,
she's looking at form. She comes and she makes
these inspo boards, you know.

And I remember as
an MBA, when she was making inspo boards, I'm
going, what are you doing? What is the purpose of that?

I can't put that
in a spreadsheet. I can't run a pivot table
on the inspiration board. And I love-- PERRY KLEBAHN: Maybe a 2 by 2.

JEREMY UTLEY: It's hard to fit
an inspiration board onto a 2 by 2, right. And yet, as I watch
her, I see that's what's

fueling her craft. I had the opportunity to teach
a class with a hip-hop artist

called Lecrae last fall. And our teaching team
was giving our students

an assignment where
we were telling them, you need to go out
and get inspiration.

You've got this problem, but
before you try to solve it, get inspired. And I could see the blank
stares on our students' faces

and I could sympathize. As a former MBA, I could see
that creativity is not even--

sorry, inspiration isn't even a
topic on the radar, let alone, you know, anything worth doing.

And I just turned to
Lecrae and I said, Lecrae, how do you think
about inspiration. I mean, he's won
multiple Grammys.

He's, you know, a wildly
productive, prolific entrepreneur and artist.

And I love what he said. He just said inspiration
is a discipline.

And to me it stood in
such stark contrast to how our students
that we were trying

to exhort to go get inspiration
thought about that topic. I think for most
people, if you think

about this topic
of inspiration, you think about the cheesy poster
in the corporate hallway.

It's like "motivation,"
or "teamwork," and that's inspiration. That's not-- when we're
talking about inspiration

and the discipline
of inspiration, we're not talking about
plastering the hallways with cheesy posters.

That's not what we
mean by this word. So we want to try
to redeem the word and give it a new definition.

PERRY KLEBAHN: Yeah,
otherwise you're not in the dentist's office. That's where I
see those posters. They always remind me of the
dentist's office, the waiting

room. Anyway, so if you want a point,
Jeremy, this is the point. You want to point to this
side, Jeremy, there we go.
Screengrab, OK. That's funny. So if you want to--

the premise of kind of what
we're going to talk about here is, in different
ways, it's you're

pursuing unexpected inputs. And if you're going
through your day pursuing these unexpected
inputs and leaving yourself

open for them, that's
the creative practice we want to help you hone
as we pump you up today.

JEREMY UTLEY: Pump you up. And it's really-- unexpected
is actually an important word-- before Perry pumps you up--

because that's how
imagination is stimulated. Imagination is stimulated
by surprising inputs.

I read a research report-- I know, I'm a nerd,
but I do that-- and it pictured an
organization like a sphere.

And it says the vast
majority of the organization has no contact with the outside
world, only the surface does.

But that's the only
part of the organization that's likely to come in contact
with an unexpected input.

And I like that as a metaphor,
that if you want to stimulate your imagination,
you need to seek out,

you need to be
deliberate about finding things you don't already know. And it requires a trip
to, or a short circuit of,

the tendencies in much of
organizational life, which is around reinforcing
what we do already know,

and doubling down, and going
in things that we've already thought about, et
cetera, et cetera.

Anyway, Perry, I interrupted
your pump up moment. PERRY KLEBAHN: That's all right. It's kind of-- I can't do
it now, that'd be weird.

So let's just move on. JEREMY UTLEY: You want to
restart the series for us. PERRY KLEBAHN: Maybe
the next slide, please.

[LAUGHTER] All right. So we'll break down
these tools and ways of creating connections.

And it reminds me,
just briefly, there's a great lecturer, a
professor at Stanford, Robert Sapolsky, who wrote
a book called Behave,

it's amazing. And I think the team, or
myself, I can't remember, we had a meeting with him and he
talked about sort of new ideas

coming from his neuroscience,
and primatologist, and all these things. But he talked about
the act of a new idea

is a lot of times just
clashing together, you know, two things you
haven't clashed together before. So Jeremy's point about
something unexpected

coming together with maybe
another problem you're trying to solve, creates
a bunch of new connections

that just yield new ideas,
things that are new to you. So that's the idea we're going
to cover, two techniques,
in this category. Or three techniques. Bonus technique. JEREMY UTLEY: Bonus technique.

PERRY KLEBAHN: This
is real time, people. This is happening right now. JEREMY UTLEY: Perry-- I'm just
trying to throw Perry off,

so I'm changing the slides
in the background real time. PERRY KLEBAHN: Because
of the slide deck, I have a copy that's
now out-of-date, so I'm like the old
operating system now.

Let's talk about
analogies first. So analogies-- well, you go
ahead, Jeremy, and run it, but without much set-up. JEREMY UTLEY: So we
want to actually do

like this nerdy thing
where you read the screen. This is an
insight-related problem.

It's called-- actually, there's
an official title of it, it's called Duncker's
radiation problem.

You might be familiar
with it if you're familiar with obscure
1930s research. It was written about in
a couple of recent books

and when we stumbled
across it, we just thought it was such a good
example of the challenge-- PERRY KLEBAHN: Should
we have Kathryn

do a voice-over
without the camera on, then it's really interactive. JEREMY UTLEY: Oh,
Kathryn, do you want to? Yeah, I--

PERRY KLEBAHN: Yeah. Kathryn, you ready? JEREMY UTLEY: She's got a--
she's got the radio voice. Let's hear it, Kathryn.

KATHRYN SEGOVIA:
"Suppose you are a doctor faced with a patient
who has a malignant stomach tumor.

It is impossible to
operate on this patient, but unless the
tumor is destroyed,

the patient will die. There is a kind of ray that can
be used to destroy the tumor.

If the rays reach
the tumor all at once in a sufficiently
high intensity,

the tumor will be destroyed. Unfortunately, at
this intensity, the healthy tissue
that the rays pass

through on the way to the
tumor will also be destroyed. At lower intensities the rays
are harmless to healthy tissue,

but they will not
affect the tumor either. What type of procedure
might be used

to destroy the tumor with
the rays and at the same time avoid destroying
the healthy tissue?

It's on you to exercise-- to excise the tumor
and save the patient, but the rays are either
too powerful or too weak.

How can you solve it?" JEREMY UTLEY: So you're
thinking about this problem. Just actually think
about it for a moment.

Don't be concerned if you
can't solve it, only about 10% of people solve it initially.

These are people from
the 1930s, probably it's different in the 2020s-- [LAUGHTER] I don't know. But, radio operator, would
you mind to continue.

KATHRYN SEGOVIA:
"While you're thinking, a little story to pass
the time: There once

was a general who
needed to capture a fortress in the middle of a
country from a brutal dictator.

If the general could get all
of his troops to the fortress at the same time, they would
have no problem taking it.

Plenty of roads that
the troops could travel radiated out from the
fort like spoke-wheels,

but they were strewn with
mines, so only small groups of soldiers could safely
traverse any one road.

The general came up with a plan. He divided the army
into small groups and each group traveled
a different road

leading to the fortress. They synchronized
their watches and made sure to converge on the
fortress at the same time

via their separate roads. The plan worked. The general captured
the fortress
and overthrew the dictator.

Have you saved the patient yet? Just one last story while
you're still thinking:

Years ago, a small town
fire chief arrived--" let me put that in
the right order--

"a small town fire chief arrived
at a woodshed fire, concerned that it would spread
to a nearby house

if it was not
extinguished quickly. There were no hydrants nearby,
but the shed was next to a lake

so there was plenty of water. Dozens of neighbors were
already taking turns with buckets throwing
water on the shed,

but they weren't
making any progress. The neighbors were surprised
when the fire chief yelled at them to stop, and to all go
fill their buckets in the lake.

When they returned,
the chief arranged them in a circle around the shed
and on the count of three

had them all throw
their water at once. The fire was immediately
dampened, and soon thereafter

extinguished. The town gave the
fire chief a pay raise as a reward for quick thinking."

JEREMY UTLEY: Can we-- so we're all looking
at each other, let's give Kathryn
some fireworks applause

for that reading. I mean that was-- that was just marvelous. Thank you, Kathryn. KATHRYN SEGOVIA: It's
story time for executives.

JEREMY UTLEY: It's story
time, exactly, right now. Please, no fast-forward button. PERRY KLEBAHN: It's a story.

JEREMY UTLEY: So
what's interesting is-- yeah, some of you are
getting it in the chat now, which is great.

The interesting thing
is the data here. Only about 10% of people
solved the problem initially.

If they hear both of the
problem and the fortress story, about 30% solved the problem.

If they hear both and the fire
chief story, half solve it. And then if they're
given those and told

to use them to help solve
the radiation problem, 80% solved the problem.

What does this tell us? It tells us that you have
to have a mindset of looking

to apply an analogy. There are rich learnings
in other fields,

but they only yield themselves
up to you if you're looking and if you're having
the attitude of--

I almost think about it as
having the attitude of I'm going to force a fit. What if I assume for
a moment that there

must be a connection between
this analogous situation and the problem I'm
trying to solve.

What might I learn from it? And a lot of times, trying
on that forcible collision--

to use Koestler's word-- trying on the collision
yields unexpected insights and possibilities that wouldn't
have come to me if I hadn't

been willing to entertain it. And we've seen it. This isn't just a
research phenomenon, we've actually seen this in
practice in many organizations

and it's a highly
effective strategy. PERRY KLEBAHN: Oh,
Jeremy, I going to tell the story in
a second, but I'm also

going to put Jeremy's
blog link in there if you want to learn more. Also, it's just Jeremy needs
a couple of ad dollars there.

So go ahead and-- JEREMY UTLEY: I don't run ads. [INTERPOSING VOICES] PERRY KLEBAHN:
--spike in traffic. JEREMY UTLEY: But you're
giving me the idea. I should set that up next time.

[LAUGHTER] PERRY KLEBAHN: Anyway,
so, for a bunch of you who came through SI&E, this
is a story we tell in that.

So this will be review
for you, new to others. We had the pleasure of working
with a team out of Fairchild

Semiconductor many,
many years ago and used a technique
using analogy-- and timely, because you've been
reading about these headlines

where there's shortages
of semiconductors. Well the challenge they had
was that small customers

would get shorted
on their orders and cause major,
major challenges. At that point,
for example, Tesla was actually a small customer.

Many of their car companies
are technically small customers because they're
using one or two, you know, chips from
a supplier per car.

But imagine if
they don't have it, you're seeing what's happening,
they can't even, you know, build a whole car.

So anyway, they had this
challenge of interruptions in supply affecting smaller
customers radically,

and they sought to
understand and use analogy to drive new ideas.

And they thought--
so what they did is, they went into the world
with this problem and said, OK, where are places we can learn
about businesses or people

that deal with
routine interruptions, but manage to still
supply their customers. And one of the places they
met-- it's a great story.

They still tell us about
going to a florist and saying, how in the world do you
promise somebody flowers

two weeks from now when
they're perishable. You know, you might have a
big order come in the day

before, like how in the
world do you deal with that. And the florist explained,
we have relationships with farmers, and we sort
of see what they're farming

and what's potentially
going to be in, and we sort of work with
that to manage expectations

of our customers in advance. And they took that back and they
used that as sort of an input to their design process and
ultimately launched a supplier,

it's called Digi-Key. It's on the internet,
but it's a different kind of supply portal
for their customers

that allows them to
see production coming from Fairchild, but also to see
suppliers from other vendors

even. So they realized what they
want to do with those smaller customers is to make sure
they-- like the florist,

they have a perspective as to
what is going to be available and what might not be available. So a good example of like
going out in the world

and seeking these
unexpected inputs. And by being open,
they suddenly noticed, we can learn a lot from a
florist and use that analog--

like the problem Jeremy
just went through-- to drive their thinking
and get to new places they wouldn't have
got to before.

JEREMY UTLEY: Yeah,
I remember distinctly the team coming back. They were very skeptical when
we said, no, go to a massage,

go to a nail salon,
go to a sushi bar, and they're like,
you're kidding, right.

But they came back and the
teams came back super energized. Kathryn was there,
remembers as well.

They were super
energized because they're learning from a florist
meaningful insights about supply chain management.

And when you
abstract a level, you say, yeah, actually it's
not an unfamiliar challenge. And the fact that it's
unfamiliar in your industry

doesn't mean that it's
unfamiliar to the world. And a lot of times if
you're thoughtful about it, and if you've taken
the innovation strategy

course in the SI&E
certificate, you probably know this method intimately, we
walk through it step-by-step.

But the world will yield
up lots of amazing insights to the person who's looking.

There's a little bit
of research that we've done on analogy that I just
figured I'd mention here.

But an analogy,
empirically-speaking, leads to more output
than a generic prompt.

That's one level. The second level is, multiple
analogies generate more output

than a single analogy does. And then the third level is,
the more distant the analogy,

the more generative it is. So you might think you've
got to stay close to be able to stay focused.

And actually a lot of
this, cultivating inputs, is about entertaining
the possibility of a collision with something
highly unrelated or highly

distant. PERRY KLEBAHN: Yeah. Yeah. And you think about
those executive teams, they're saying, well, no,
no, no, I want a benchmark,

I want to look at what
our competitors are doing. But by going--
this is critical, I like that point,
Jeremy-- by going beyond,

to a florist that
has nothing whatever to do with our business, that's
where the big idea came from.

So again, we're in this
sort of driving connection. This idea of a wonder
wander is something

that we now assign
routinely in our classes. Jeremy and I are known to do
this also on a daily basis.

The basic idea is, if you
have a clear sort of frame on a problem, a clear
thing you're working on,

one of the best things you
can do is actually step away. So right now, if I said how
do I make this talk more

interesting, the
best thing I could do is walk outside
with just the idea of how do I make that
more interesting, ruminate, go for a walk.

And by holding that
in my head that I'm trying to be more
interesting, I might see a couple of dogs
playing, I might

get inspiration from
the outside world, and just drive more inputs. It's important you go
out with an objective.

And then I would bring
something with me. We'll talk about
this at the end, but if you bring that pad
of Post-its, or a notebook, to write these things down.

And I would sort
of come back and be able to have more material
with which to innovate.

You know, this unrelented
sort of pursuit, I'd have new inputs to my
practice, to get inspired.

Jeremy does this, we oftentimes
are working on something, will say, OK, let's
both step away. But hold each other
accountable, like we're

going to go work on this frame. Jeremy, truth be told, does live
close to a McDonald's that does [INAUDIBLE],, or a Jack in
the Box that does involve

milkshakes-- [INTERPOSING VOICES] JEREMY UTLEY: I'm
going to say it. I find, I find the-- PERRY KLEBAHN: The guy
has a lot of milkshakes.

But, anyway, that's
one little bonus to this effort I would say JEREMY UTLEY: The viscosity of
the milkshake, just the effort

required, just the pure
mechanical effort, it just-- it's like it
sucks ideas into my head. I mean it's really,
it's truly incredible.

PERRY KLEBAHN: And
as you wanted it. The key thing is
writing it down. and we'll get back
to that at the end. JEREMY UTLEY: So we
said that we were

going to cover a third
topic on how do you accelerate connections. PERRY KLEBAHN: This is the
bonus topic, I love it.

JEREMY UTLEY: The bonus topic. But wait, Perry, it's
actually not a bonus topic because we realized there's so
much interest in these topics,

we said, let's make it
it's own talk next time. So there's-- PERRY KLEBAHN: This is a
teaser, so sign up now--

JEREMY UTLEY: Yeah, exactly. PERRY KLEBAHN: --and
you can get this. JEREMY UTLEY: Sign
up now, 49.99, and you'll get a free
gift with purchase.

No, we wanted-- the
topic of collaboration, and diverse perspectives, and
leveraging, and amplifying

diverse perspectives,
it's such a worthy topic, it's actually an entirely
other session on its own.

And we've learned a ton
from amazing leadership teams, and design teams,
and innovation teams, and creatives that
we've worked with,

we just want to dedicate
an entire talk to that. So it is a little
bit of a teaser, but I would say there's
so many rich stories,

it's not worth giving it
a one-minute treatment, it's worth giving it a
significant treatment.

So we've talked
about connection, but now I want to
talk about something that's unexpected for folks. If you think about
input-obsession, disconnection.

Disconnection is
actually a critical part of realizing new connections. Have you ever had
this experience?

and there's like five
things that I really need to attend to, and then
immediately, somebody else is on my screen in
the next meeting.

And I totally forget
all of the other things that I was just thinking about. There's great ideas, there's
stuff I need to take care of,

right, and then that
meeting culminates, and a bunch of other
things then immediately get forgotten, right.

Without disconnection,
we don't harvest the possibility
of the connections

that we've been seeking. And part of-- when we talk about
being obsessed with inputs,

part of what is required
is that creative thinkers and innovators make space
to make the connections that

happen in their minds and not
rush from thing, to thing, to thing, to thing. It's really, really
hard to do this,

but we find it's absolutely
critical to make the space to realize connections.

Our brains aren't efficient. They're efficient
in a lot of ways, you know, you can't power
a brain size network,

or a brain power network with
basically all the power we have available at our disposal,
so incredibly efficient

in some sense. But they're actually driven
by, and unexpected connections are driven by, an inefficient
process that oftentimes happens

at a subconscious level. And as we're hyper-efficiency,
oriented-driven from productivity,
you know, meeting,

to meeting, to meeting, we fail
to maximize those connections.

One of our favorite
researchers, Amos Tversky, he was the partner, or
the research partner

of Danny Kahneman. If he had lived, he would have
been the co-winner of the Nobel Prize with Danny Kahneman. But they invented the field
of behavioral psychology

and behavioral
economics, the notion that people aren't rational.

Among others, we have these two
incredibly brilliant gentlemen to thank.

They devised a
bunch of incredibly insightful and
creative experiments. Part of their
breakthroughs was because

their experimental
design was so creative. You can read about this. Mike Lewis, the author of
The Big Short and Moneyball,

he wrote a great book on them
called The Undoing Project, if you're curious about where
this psychology comes from.

But when somebody asked
Tversky once, how did you and Kahneman come up with
so many cool experiments.

This is what he
said, we wasted time. And he said, people waste
years by not being able

to waste hours. And the joke around
their department-- they were at a
university in Israel,

the joke around their
department is those guys are laughing too much. It wasn't a joke, it was more
of a comment on derision,

they're always laughing,
they're always cutting up. And yet what they knew was
that a little bit of loose time

was critical for them to realize
the value of new connections. And so I want to
talk for a second

about a little bit of the
dorky side of psychology. So if you read the literature-- I mean there's a bunch of
different ways to parse it,

so this isn't meant to be
a comprehensive or perfect explanation. But if you think
about what's happening

in the creative mindset, there
is a stage of preparation. There's a stage of incubation.

There's a stage of
illumination, which is the Aha! moment, right. And then there's a
stage of verification.

What we have observed casually--
this isn't a clinical diagnosis because I'm not a
clinical psychologist,

but I would say one of the
most short-circuited processes in the 21st century
is incubation,

giving our brain the soup
space to connect things.

And so, when we talk
about not just connection, but disconnection, part
of the underlying idea

there is that
disconnection is actually part of what fuels connection. And if we're not deliberate
about disconnecting,

we won't be able to realize
those new connections. So we want to talk about-- PERRY KLEBAHN: Well oftentimes
